docs.abstract: Asian-American women--who tend not to smoke, drink or be overweight--are found by Commonwealth Fund study to have lower mortality rate for a number of major diseases than white women, despite fact that they also tend to have fewer screening tests (Special section, Women's Health) (S)
docs.snippet: When it comes to staying healthy, what you don't do -- like smoke, drink or overeat -- seems to be more important than how often you undergo screening tests, if the experience of Asian-American women is an indication. In 1991 and 1992, according to...
docs.lead_paragraph: When it comes to staying healthy, what you don't do -- like smoke, drink or overeat -- seems to be more important than how often you undergo screening tests, if the experience of Asian-American women is an indication. In 1991 and 1992, according to the National Cancer Institute, Asian women had lower rates of Pap test, mammography and clinical breast exam than any other racial or ethnic group in the United States. Even so, a Commonwealth Fund women's health survey reports that from 1986 to 1990, they had a lower age-adjusted mortality rate than white women for heart disease, stroke, lung cancer, breast cancer, diabetes, colorectal cancer, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and cervical cancer.

docs.abstract: Central tenet of the women's health movement has been that women should be in control of their health and medical care, but the reality the movement has helped to create is more complex; doctors now discuss choices and treatments more than they used to, but when medical issues involve complex choices and potentially deadly diseases, patients often seek to have doctors make decisions for them; photo (Special section, Women's Health) (M)
docs.snippet: DR. RICHARD PAULSON of the University of Southern California was startled when a woman in his infertility program, who said she was 53, turned out to be 63. After all, he had set a limit of 55 on how old a woman could be to receive an egg from a...
docs.lead_paragraph: DR. RICHARD PAULSON of the University of Southern California was startled when a woman in his infertility program, who said she was 53, turned out to be 63. After all, he had set a limit of 55 on how old a woman could be to receive an egg from a younger woman to become pregnant. It was a limit based, as most such limits are, not so much on medical concerns as on what the doctor considered to be appropriate. The case, which made headlines when the woman became the oldest on record to give birth, raised not only the issue of age and pregnancy, but also the question of how much control women should have over matters involving their own bodies.

headline.main: Women Want Control, Just Not All of the Time

docs.abstract: Women's health movement, which has brought steadily increasing numbers of women into medical sechools, has also brought a quiet revolution to medical teaching, with increasing focus on the physical and psychological distinctions between men and women; doctors in training program on women's health at Veterans Affairs Medical Center in Durham, NC, comment; photo (Special section, Women's Health) (M)
docs.snippet: MUCH has changed in medical training since the days when anatomy professors ordered students to discard the breasts from female cadavers.    Signs of how far things have changed at schools and hospitals around the United States are evident even in...
docs.lead_paragraph: MUCH has changed in medical training since the days when anatomy professors ordered students to discard the breasts from female cadavers. Signs of how far things have changed at schools and hospitals around the United States are evident even in the overwhelmingly male environment of the Veterans Affairs Medical Center here. The hospital not only has a bright new clinic for treating its 1,400 female patients, but is also home to a fellowship and a student-training program that focuses on women and their health.

headline.main: A Lesson for Residents: They're Not Like Men

docs.abstract: Decade of lobbying for women's health issues is beginning to pay off, as Federal and other allotments for research into diseases that affect mainly women grows; most stunning example is Federal money directed toward breast cancer; chart (Special section, Women's Health) (M)
docs.snippet: ANYONE looking for proof of the political clout attached to women's health issues can find it in the place that provides the truest test of such importance: the fine print of the Federal budget process.    The Congressional committees that write the...
docs.lead_paragraph: ANYONE looking for proof of the political clout attached to women's health issues can find it in the place that provides the truest test of such importance: the fine print of the Federal budget process. The Congressional committees that write the Government's health-research budget have studded their reports in recent years with demands for more research on disorders, large and small, that predominantly affect women. Such prodding has helped create a top-level office in the National Institutes of Health to oversee research on women's ailments, and a similar post, deputy assistant secretary for women's health, for the Department of Health and Human Services.

headline.main: In Research, the Sincerest Form of Concern Is Money

docs.abstract: New York Times/CBS News poll finds that women are more afraid of cancer than any other disease and are most anxious about breast cancer; women are also more aggressive than the medical establishment when it comes to screening, with 44 percent favoring regular mammograms from age 40 and another 40 percent favoring the test at even earlier ages; researchers are sharply divided over whether mammograms are worthwile for women under age 50; photos; charts (Special section, Women's Health) (M)
docs.snippet: WOMEN are more afraid of cancer than any other disease and are most anxious about breast cancer. Even though heart disease kills more women, this fear is not surprising: almost 40 percent of women say that a close female relative has received a...
docs.lead_paragraph: WOMEN are more afraid of cancer than any other disease and are most anxious about breast cancer. Even though heart disease kills more women, this fear is not surprising: almost 40 percent of women say that a close female relative has received a diagnosis of breast cancer, and three-quarters say they have been following the recent controversy over how often women of different ages should have mammograms, according to a New York Times/CBS News poll. These worries also appear to be making women far more aggressive than the medical establishment when it comes to screening. While researchers are divided sharply over whether mammograms are generally worthwhile for women younger than 50, an overwhelming majority of women 40 and over in the survey have had at least one mammogram, and a third of women in their 30's have had at least a base-line mammogram. The nationwide telephone survey, conducted May 19 through 23 with 859 women, has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 4 percentage points.

headline.main: On Breast Cancer, the Vote Favors Aggressive Screening

docs.snippet: In the last decade, there has beem explosion of information about women's health. Here is a selective list of resources recommended by staff writers of The New York Times and by experts in the field. Information from these sources should not be...
docs.lead_paragraph: In the last decade, there has beem explosion of information about women's health. Here is a selective list of resources recommended by staff writers of The New York Times and by experts in the field. Information from these sources should not be considered a substitute for consultation with a health professional. An expanded version is available on the Inernet. The New York Times on the Web: www.nytimes.com. Books

docs.abstract: Article by Dr Lawrence K Altman assesses the truism that women are sicker but live longer than men; says there is no hard data indicating that women are less healthy, although women seek medical attention more often; rather, research suggests that women and men spend similar proportions of their lives without disability; women now live about seven years longer than men, and on average are disability free for first five of those years (Special section, Women's Health) (M)
docs.snippet: TO EMPHASIZE the differences in the health of the sexes, Dr. Eugenia Eng tells students at the University of North Carolina, ''Women are sicker; men die quicker.'' That women in the United States live about seven years longer than men is hardly...
docs.lead_paragraph: TO EMPHASIZE the differences in the health of the sexes, Dr. Eugenia Eng tells students at the University of North Carolina, ''Women are sicker; men die quicker.'' That women in the United States live about seven years longer than men is hardly disputed, though the reason for the gap is a mystery. The perception that women are sicker, not only in their extra years but throughout life, is also widely shared and used to counteract the notion that women are healthier because they live longer. It is also used to justify the need for more health care for women and the way in which research money is allocated.

headline.main: Is the Longer Life The Healthier One?

docs.abstract: Market continues to boom in weight-loss drugs, despite warnings about side effects, doubts about efficacy, and doctors' widespread prescribing to patients who do not qualify as obese; photo (Special section, Women's Health) (S)
docs.snippet: WEIGHT-LOSS experts have yet to create a silver bullet for fighting fat, but consumers are searching harder than ever for one. From 1995 to 1996, sales of anti-obesity drugs nearly tripled to $526 million from $179 million.     Obesity ranks second...
docs.lead_paragraph: WEIGHT-LOSS experts have yet to create a silver bullet for fighting fat, but consumers are searching harder than ever for one. From 1995 to 1996, sales of anti-obesity drugs nearly tripled to $526 million from $179 million. Obesity ranks second to smoking as a cause of preventable death in the United States, contributing to 300,000 deaths a year. But while there are no reliable numbers, medical practitioners think that much of the increase in drug sales was going not to the seriously obese but to the merely heavy, said Dr. Louis Aronne, who runs a weight-loss clinic affiliated with New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center.

headline.main: Despite Warnings, the Sales of Diet Drugs Soar

docs.abstract: Publication in 1970 of book Our Bodies, Ourselves, written by and for women, was watershed event in the women's health movement; the authors, members of the Boston Women's Health Collective, are still at work on the latest edition, and the book has sold more than four million copies in 15 languages; authors comment; their photos, then and now (Special section, Women's Health) (M)
docs.snippet: JANE PINCUS is again writing the childbirth chapter. Nancy Miriam Hawley is working on the one about psychotherapy. Wendy Sanford is rewriting the section on AIDS. Norma Swenson is taking on the politics of women and medical care. Judy Norsigian is...
docs.lead_paragraph: JANE PINCUS is again writing the childbirth chapter. Nancy Miriam Hawley is working on the one about psychotherapy. Wendy Sanford is rewriting the section on AIDS. Norma Swenson is taking on the politics of women and medical care. Judy Norsigian is writing about contraceptives. And Paula Doress-Worters is handling the topic of women and aging. They were young and married, mothers or pregnant, most of them, when they began meeting in Cambridge, Mass., in the early days of the women's movement. Now, nearly 30 years later, they are working on what they have been working on since the start: ''Our Bodies, Ourselves,'' the book whose frank discussions of birth control, abortion, pregnancy, childbirth, sexuality and other subjects revolutionized the way women's health care was discussed and delivered.

headline.main: They Talked and Talked, and Then Wrote a Classic

docs.abstract: Interview with Debbie Lee of the Family Violence Prevention Fund on how doctors and other medical professionals can help victims of domestic violence; photo (Special section, Women's Health) (M)
docs.snippet: IN THE 1970's, the criminal justice system in the United States woke up to the problem of domestic violence. Since then, women's advocates and policy makers nationwide have been pushing the health care system to focus on domestic violence as a public...
docs.lead_paragraph: IN THE 1970's, the criminal justice system in the United States woke up to the problem of domestic violence. Since then, women's advocates and policy makers nationwide have been pushing the health care system to focus on domestic violence as a public health problem that sends thousands of women to hospital emergency rooms each year. They have succeeded: in 1994, the American Medical Association issued diagnostic and treatment guidelines on domestic violence, finding that the problem is so prevalent that doctors should routinely and directly ask all women about abuse -- not just in emergency rooms but in primary care, prenatal clinics and other health settings.

headline.main: Seeking a Public Health Solution for a Problem That Starts at Home
